title: Who are the favourites for Paris-Roubaix 2023?
content:
Cyclist
Who are the favourites for Paris-Roubaix 2023?

Paris-Roubaix, Hell of the North, Queen of the Classics, it’s the Game of Thrones of cycling races and it is risen once again on Easter Weekend, thank the gods.

With the women safe from Annemiek van Vleuten and the men safe from Tadej Pogačar, both pelotons will roar through the cobbles of northern France with the hopes of scoring the big one (cobble) at the Roubaix Velodrome come the end of Saturday and Sunday for women and men respectively.

Well, theoretically, because of course those two behemoths wouldn’t be favoured to win a race this flat anyway. Instead it will be the real powerhouses of pro cycling who come out to play on the toughest Classic of them all, and there are a couple of riders who are seen as shoe-ins for the podium. So, who should you look out for and who will win Paris-Roubaix 2023?

Women’s Paris-Roubaix 2023 favourites

While there is minimal betting to hint at who the ‘official’ favourites are for Paris-Roubaix Femmes, there are three is one standout contender to be the queen of the Queen of the Classics.

Lotte Kopecky

Lotte Kopecky says her main goal for this season is Paris-Roubaix. That is scary. Kopecky has been utterly supreme in 2023, only coming unstuck at Strade Bianche, when she was pipped to the line by her own teammate. She came second here in 2022 and if she doesn’t win it’ll be an upset.

After such an imperious display at her home race the Tour of Flanders last weekend when she was also expected to win, you can be sure she won’t be phased by expectations, and Roubaix suits her better than Flanders anyway, with a massive engine and a mighty sprint if she’s not alone in the velodrome. It’s Kopecky’s to lose.

Elisa Longo Borghini

Defending champion Elisa Longo Borghini had to take some time out this season after contracting Covid, but her return to racing saw 11th at Dwars door Vlaanderen and a hard-fought third at the Tour of Flanders. With the hills her undoing in De Ronde and with an extra week of recovery, Longo Borghini should absolutely be competing for back-to-back Roubaixs on Saturday.

If not, she has the fortune of being on the only team to ever win Paris-Roubaix Femmes (albeit there’s only one winner other than her), and teammates Lucinda Brand, Elisa Balsamo and Shirin van Anrooij could all do a job should Longo Borghini not be on a good day.

Marianne Vos

Marianne Vos won’t want to retire without a Paris-Roubaix cobble on her mantlepiece. The race suits her down to the ground with her abilities off-road and huge engine, she came second to Lizzie Deignan in the rain in 2021 but was a DNS in 2022.

Three race days so far this year have been top 20s in the very hilly Trofeo Alfredo Binda and Tour of Flanders, and third at the flatter Dwars door Vlaanderen. At the berg-less Roubaix, will Vos be boss?

The outsiders

In order, you should also be keeping your eyes on: Lucinda Brand, Silvia Persico, Shirin van Anrooij, Lorena Wiebes, Pfeiffer Georgi, Marta Bastianelli, Elise Chabbey and Floortje Mackaij.

Men’s Paris-Roubaix 2023 favourites

While the GOAT, Tadej Pogačar, won’t be lining up to add a fourth Monument to his set on Sunday, this generation’s greatest rivalry will be going at it again and unsurprisingly they’re the bookies’ favourites, alongside a few equally capable riders with a massive opportunity.

Wout van Aert

The tables have turned, and Wout van Aert is the favourite for this one after Mathieu van der Poel was favoured for Flanders. Van Aert finished second last year behind now-teammate Dylan van Baarle, so that’s one challenger down already. Yes he didn’t make the final selection last weekend but the lack of hills will help keep his legs fresh and enable his teammates to stay at the front of the race for longer.

A win here would be absolutely huge for Wout’s legacy, with only one Monument to his name so far to Van der Poel’s three, and he looks well placed to do it. He’s Johan Museeuw’s pick.

Mathieu van der Poel

While Wout has been cleaning up the semi-Classics, Van der Poel has a Monument win and Monument runner-up. He seems truly at his best in 2023 and that is frightening for anyone else with hopes of victory. He’ll need to be forced into tricky situations like getting dropped in crosswinds in Flanders or like getting completely cooked and giving an actual sprinter a free ride in Roubaix 2021.

Winning on Sunday would turn MvdP’s season from incredible to legendary, and a third Monument to match Tadej Pogačar’s tally and leave just two for the set would be massive. Although he’s a lot less likely to get all five with the Lombardia parcours, with Van der Poel you absolutely would not write him off. If he doesn’t win Roubaix in his career it’ll be seen as a massive failure for a rider with such road and off-road pedigree. He’ll certainly be up for it.

Mads Pedersen

Mads Pedersen really wants to win Paris-Roubaix and the race suits the Dane down to the cobbled ground. Known to thrive in the most difficult conditions, he’s the northern Wout with sprinting his forte but hills not out of his reach and Classics certainly his wheelhouse. He put in a strong shift in Flanders to beat Van Aert in the sprint for third and spent a while leading the race solo. If his legs survived, he’ll be at the front again. The former World Champion has been doubted despite his achievements and winning Roubaix would put any of that to bed. The bookies have him as third favourite, so clearly not everyone doubts him. The forecast is dry though.

Filippo Ganna

Filippo Ganna had been written in as a Paris-Roubaix winner before he’d ever taken to the cobbles, and he didn’t have the ideal race on his debut in 2022, but his teammate won, so it was a success right? Paris-Roubaix suits riders with big engines and engines don’t come bigger than the Hour Record dominator. He won’t want to come to the finish with any of the aforementioned names, but he has shown off a mighty sprint this year, including at Milan-San Remo, where he beat Wout van Aert into second. After sacrificing road form for the Hour in 2022, Ganna’s hoping his next scalp is Paris-Roubaix, and when he wins that? No one is safe. The new Merckx?

Dylan van Baarle

The 2022 winner, now with the assistance of the 2022 runner-up and still not being the favourite, and with fresh legs after sitting out the Tour of Flanders, Dylan van Baarle is set up incredibly well to go back-to-back in Roubaix. Like Ganna he’ll want to finish alone, but as we know by now Van Baarle has no issues in achieving that, somehow sneaking off the front of races consistently despite everyone knowing what he can do. His fate rests on whether he needs to help Wout or whether he’ll be able to ride as a co-leader, using the other contenders’ focus on Van Aert would be ideal to slip off the front once more.

The outsiders

Look out for: Matej Mohorič, Stefan Küng, Yves Lampaert, Kasper Asgreen, Alexander Kristoff and Jasper Stuyven.

The Cyclist predictions

Lotte Kopecky is a lock. Matej Mohorič is out to win Roubaix and finished fifth in 2022 but came in with the same time as Van Aert in second. Big names watching each other will allow the Slovenian to bag a second Monument.

Keep your eyes on Iván García Cortina in the men’s race though, he will win something big soon. Book it.
